title: Validate a product key
description: Need help in validating a Windows 11 pro product key
answers:
Please provide more information.
Why? Does it not work when you
try to enter it?
Is it from 1 PC to another?
Did you buy Windows 11 Pro from a 3rd party?
It may not be genuine.
See if something in this link helps:
[https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/answers/questions/3993742/error-as-0xc004f050-(the-product-key-you-enter-did](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/answers/questions/3993742/error-as-0xc004f050-(the-product-key-you-enter-did)
Good luck

title: Recent Windows Security and Feature Update was a disaster for my PC.
description:
On 9/8 or 9/9 there was a Windows Update that obliterated my accessibility peripherals on my computer, leaving me unable to access my computer to work. Despite lengthy tech support assistance from Dell, I was advised to reset my computer to a new version of the Windows operating system that was on my system. Before the reset, I initiated the "save my OneDrive account", music, and videos. After the reset, I have some files, but not my Documents folder and Pictures folder. I know OneDrive has my files and Word, but a technician said the link is broken, and I don't know what the heck he was talking about so I quickly got off the phone with him. The weird thing is the recovery process pulled files from different users, like my partner's and my deceased mother-in-law's computer, and I don't know how that happened. They were never users on my computer.
If someone can share a Tech Support number or how I can access my OneDrive, Word, Documents, and Pictures folders, I would greatly appreciate it.
answers:
Dear michaifreeman-2034
Thanks for reaching out! Welcome to Microsoft Q&A.Â I'm Haien fromÂ Microsoft Q&A.Â 
From what you've described, a security update around September 9, 2025 (likely KB5065431 for Windows 11 versions 22H2/23H2 or KB5065426 for 24H2) may have caused driver conflicts with your accessibility peripherals, leading to the need for a reset.
If I've misunderstood any details (e.g., exact update date or how the other users' files appeared), could you clarify? Also, what version of Windows 11 are you on now (check in Settings > System > About)? In the meantime, you can try these workarounds to check your PC:

 Go to onedrive.live.com and sign in with your Microsoft account > Browse to Documents and Pictures folders to download files manually > In OneDrive web, go toÂ Recycle bin > Select files > Restore.
 Right-click the OneDrive icon in the taskbarÂ > Settings > Account > Unlink this PC >Â Restart your PCÂ >Â Sign back into OneDrive and choose to sync Documents and Pictures.
 If issues persist, reset OneDrive: Press Win + R, type %localappdata%\Microsoft\OneDrive\onedrive.exe /reset, and hitÂ Enter. It will resync everything.


For additional information about reset OneDrive, please visit this article to know more:Â Reset OneDrive - Microsoft Support

Please keep me updated with anything new that you were try to each option.
To assist others who might have similar questions and to help us improve our support system, we kindly encourage you to "Accept the answer" if it successfully addressed your concern. Accepting an answer lets other users know that this solution worked for you, and it also helps us track the effectiveness of our support efforts.
We appreciate your patience and look forward to resolving this quickly for you.
Warm regards

title: This issue relates specifically to the Windows Copilot app - Windows Copilot App Launches in Oversized Window on Multi-Monitor Setup
description:
One question first: There is no Copilot tag under Windows 11. It should be, I think.
The Copilot App problem Description:
Copilot app on a multi-monitor setup. When launched, the app opens in an oversized "monster" windowâoften spanning multiple screens and ignoring saved window state.
The problem appeared the first time after the August 2025 update and disappeared. It appeared again after the September update. Both Windows and the Copilot app are on the latest level.
Observed Behavior:

 Copilot launches in a massive window, not respecting previous size or position
 Resizing manually works temporarily, but the issue returns on relaunch
 Behavior persists across reboots and display configuration changes
 I have discovered that the Copilot app at its start opens in the minimized window which spreads across two monitors.

As a workaround I have reduced this monster size minimized window to a smaller size which can fit on the monitor.  Clicking on the window maximize icon restores the app window. If the Copilot app is stopped with the window in its maximized size it will open next time again in the minimized size, except that it is now acceptable.
System Context:

 Windows 11 Pro, latest updates installed
 Dual-monitor setup (primary 1080p, secondary 1080p)
 Copilot app pinned to taskbar, launched via Win+C or icon

Troubleshooting Attempts:

 Verified registry entries for window metricsâno persistent fix
 Checked for Copilot-specific settings or flagsânone found

Is there a known workaround or registry tweak to enforce window size/position on launch? Or is this a bug that needs escalation?
Happy to share logs or test solutionsâthis is part of a broader workflow protocol Iâm refining for reproducible UI behavior.
answers:
Hi,
There have been changes to Copilot after the September Patch Tuesday Update KB5065426. Perhaps the update introduced a bug thatâs causing the behavior youâre experiencing. I havenât come across other cases matching yours, but if resetting the app didnât help, itâs most likely a bug. In this case, I recommend reporting the issue. The latest app version doesnât seem to include a feedback option, but you can go to the Copilot website, click on your avatar, and select Give feedback. From there, youâll be able to attach a recording, along with samples and log files, to help the team investigate and resolve the problem.

title: KB5065426 update stops file and print sharing from working
description:
I was having issues with multiple locations using windows file and print sharing with password sharing. I found windows update KB5065426 was installed and that my file and print sharing options were turned off. I also found that networks were set to public that had previously sent to private. 
Even after setting the settings back, the computers would not working with file and print sharing and I had to uninstall the update to get the functionality to work.
answers:
It is great that Hendrik provided a "potential" solution, but as others have mentioned this does not actually solve the problem.
Likewise I found the ONLY way to make network sharing work again is to uninstall the KB5065426!!!
Having a patch from Microsoft which kills network sharing is extremely poor and will likely affect thousands of people who shre files at home or many SMB.  
Microsoft - wake up and fix this issue!
I have performed additional tests using some machines which were cloned (thus having the same machine Security Identifier (machine SID)) with and without KB5065426 applied to Windows 11 24H2. 
If KB5065426 is installed, then file or print sharing between any cloned computer with same machine Security Identifier (machine SID) - FAILS.
If KB5065426 is uninstalled, then file or print sharing between any cloned computer with same machine Security Identifier (machine SID) - WORKS.
If KB5065426 is installed, then file or print sharing between any computer which has different machine Security Identifier (machine SID) - WORKS.
So it seems clear that now after decades Microsoft has killed/blocked file sharing and printer sharing due the same machine SID.
Microsoft - wake up and fix this issue!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  or provide a way to disable the machine SID check
To validate that it is the machine SID which is the root cause of failed microsoft file sharing between PCs when both computers have KB5065426 installed, I conducted the following test.  

 I made two identical virtual machines which I confirmed had the same machine SID as my desktop.
 The first virtual machine copy was used as the reference machine and would always refuse to connect to my desktop windows share (constantly asking for username & password).
 The second virtual machine copy as one would expect also did not connect to my desktop windows share (constantly asking for username & password).  But this is expected if the machine SID is the cause.
 On the second virtual machine copy, I then use the tool SIDCHG to change the machine SID and allowed it to reboot.
 On the second virtual machine copy, I checked and confirmed that the machine SID had been changed and was now different to the other VM and my desktop machine SID.
 On the second virtual machine copy, I then attempted to connect to the network share on my desktop and it worked  exactly as it should :)
 So the only thing which changed in all of this was the machine SID of the second virtual machine copy. 
 Now that I had validated this hypothesis usign some virtual machines, I found another cloned PC with same machine SID which was exhibiting the same failure to connect to my desktop windows share (constantly asking for username & password). After changing the machine SID with SIDCHG on that computer and rebooting, it could then access the network share on my desktop without constantly asking for username & password time & time again.

Also be aware in some instances, I have also seen KB5065426 disable file & print sharing, so you may find sometimes this needs to be re-enabled.
In a few other test I have also noticed that after KB5065426 a network can inexplicably be changed from being  private to public or vice versa.
Same problem all the share in the local area network are lost, unable to connect to any share, this problem is caused by  some windows updates named : KB5064081 and KB5065426,  sometimes solved by removing it.
Microsoft - wake up and fix this issue!
Hi Kevin OBrien,
Thank you for reaching out regarding the issues you experienced with file and print sharing after installing Windows Update KB5065426. We understand how critical this functionality is for your workflow, and we appreciate your patience.

FYI, the KB5065426 update introduced security enhancements that:

 Reset some network profiles from Private to Public.
 Disabled File and Printer Sharing and Network Discovery.
 Blocked insecure guest logons by default for better protection.

As a result, even after re-enabling sharing settings, connections may fail if these new security requirements are not addressed. Removing KB5065426 restores functionality but also removes important security fixes.
Here a step-by-step guide to address the issue without removing the KB5065426 update, please kindly follow:
1 - Set Your Network to Private

 Go to Settings â Network & Internet.
 Select your active network and set it to Private.

2 - Turn On Sharing Features

 Navigate to Settings â Network & Internet â Advanced Network Settings â Network and Sharing Center â Change Advanced Sharing Settings.
 Enable:

 Turn on network discovery
 Turn on file and printer sharing



3 - Allow Guest Access (If needed)
For Windows Home:

 Open Registry Editor and go to: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\LanmanWorkstation\Parameters
 Create a DWORD named AllowInsecureGuestAuth and set its value to 1.

4 - Check SMB Settings
If older devices require it, enable SMB 1.0/CIFS File Sharing Support:

 Control Panel â Programs â Turn Windows features on or off.

5 - Restart All Devices

 After applying these changes, restart both the sharing and client computers.


I look forward to receiving your update and I'm willing to collaborate with you till we resolve the issue. Please keep me informed.

title: How to transfer files from my personal OneDrive to a business OneDrive
description:
On my personal Windows 11 Home laptop I have set the Windows screenshot destination folder to be located on my personal OneDrive account. I have also been assigned a OneDrive account associated with the charity Inland Waterways Association at waterways.org.uk. When I capture waterways-related screenshots, I wish to transfer them to the waterways account for succession planning. 
While using my personal OneDrive account, I could not find an option to move/copy files to a different OneDrive account. Is it possible to do this?
I have considered a different approach, that is to change the Windows screenshot destination folder to the waterways account, but this would likely lead to confusion and result in personal files being wrongly located.
answers:
Hello
Do you have OneDrive app running for both accounts?
If not, you can set up a personal and a business accounts in OneDrive and have them running at the same time.   
Go to the cloud icon on the taskbar, click on it and go to Settings > Accounts tab, there you can add your second account. 
Once added, you should see a gray cloud (personal) and a blue cloud (business) on your taskbar.   
In your File Explorer, you will see two Onedrive folders. One for personal, one for business. Go to the personal folder, find the screenshots folder (might be in Pictures folder), copy the files from there, then go to your business folder and paste them.

title: Windows 11, version 24H2 download error
description:
Hi! 
My computer keeps failing in downloading the latest update for windows. I ranun the Windows update troubleshooter, but this didn`t help. I also tried these steps from another post on this page: 
"Method 2: Reset Windows Components
Enter "Command Prompt" into the Windows search box, then right-click and select "Run as administrator" to proceed. After the Command Prompt opens, input the following commands and press Enter after each:
net stop bits
net stop wuauserv
net stop appidsvc
net stop cryptsvc
Ren C:\Windows\SoftwareDistribution.old
Ren C:\Windows\System32\catroot2 Catroot2.old
net start bits
net start wuauserv
net start appidsvc
net start cryptsvc
Restart your PC then try to update again."
This didnt help either. I dont know much about computers, but is there anything else I can do that is not to complicated to follow instructions? It is really bothering me that I can`t update.
answers:
Hi. I'm David, and I'm happy to help you.

Please clarify the following:
Are you getting an error code? If yes, which one?
If you don't get an error code, see the update history.

 Press "Windows + I" and select "Windows Update > Update history".

If you prefer, share a screenshot. Use the shortcut "Windows + Shift + S" to use the screenshot tool.

Also. What is the current version and "OS Build" of your Windows 11?

 Press "Windows + R", type winver, and click OK.

If you prefer, share a screenshot.
Be sure to censor your email address if it appears. The Microsoft Q&A is public.

I await your reply.
Use this website
https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/software-download/windows11
and download either a Windows 11 24H2 ISO (which you can mount with your current Windows) or the media creation tool to make a bootable USB or DVD. In both cases you can choose either to upgrade your current version or do a clean install.
Thanks for the clarifications.

Try upgrading to version 24H2 by doing an In-place Upgrade using an ISO file.
But don't worry. It's a simple procedure, and you have the option to keep files, settings, and apps. Therefore, all your data is kept.
(If you have a third-party antivirus installed, temporarily disable it during the entire procedure.)

Download the ISO file to perform the procedure:

 Access the link below;

https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/software-download/windows11

 Under "Download Windows 11 Disk Image (ISO)", click "Select download" and select "Windows 11 (multi-edition ISO for x64 devices)";
 Click "Download";
 Choose the language and click on "Confirm";
 Then, click "64-bit Download".
 Wait for the download to finish and proceed to the procedure below.


After downloading the ISO, do the following:

 Double-click the ISO to run;

(After running the ISO, you may need to double-click the "Setup" file to start the procedure.)

 On the "Install Windows 11" screen, uncheck "I want to help make the installation of Windows better" and select "Change how Windows Setup download updates";
 On the next screen, select "Not right now" and click "Next";
 Accept the terms of use;
 On the "Ready to install" screen, select "Choose what to keep" and select what you want to keep.

(It is in this step that you must check "Keep personal files and apps" so that all your data is kept.)

 Click on "Install" and wait for the procedure to finish. Your computer may restart several times.


At the end of the procedure, your Windows 11 will be in the latest version (24H2), and the update may already be installed. But check Windows Update to be sure.

If you get any errors, please let me know.

Feel free to ask back any questions.

I am trying, but after clicking on confirm, nothing happens. I don`t get download option. It has been over 5 minutes now, since I clicked on it. I turned off the virus protection while trying this, too.

title: Would all my data etc from old laptop fit on a 32GB memory stick?
description: I am upgrading to windows 11 laptop and need to transfer all data,files,downloads,pictures,passwords to new laptop.
answers:
Dear A T,
Thank you for reaching out to the Microsoft Q&A.
To give you a direct answer: It is highly unlikely that all the data from your old laptop will fit on a 32GB memory stick.
While it's possible if you have only used your computer for a very small number of documents and photos, most people accumulate far more data than that over a few years of use. Think of it this way: a single 10-minute video from a modern smartphone can be over 1GB, and a large photo library can easily exceed 30GB on its own.
You can buy an external hard drive (HDD) or a faster external solid-state drive (SSD) with 1 Terabyte (1TB = 1,000GB) of storage for a very reasonable price. This gives you more than enough space for the transfer and can be used as a regular backup device afterward.
You can also use Cloud Storage (OneDrive or Google Drive) to transfer your files. Moreover, it also creates a backup.

To assist others who might have similar questions and to help us improve our support system, we kindly encourage you to "Accept the answer" if it successfully addressed your concern. Accepting an answer lets other users know that this solution worked for you, and it also helps us track the effectiveness of our support efforts.
No-one can know that for sure.
Open File Explorer, then go to C:\Users then go into your user folder.
Select the Documents, Pictures, Videos, Music, Downloads and Desktop folders, then right click them and select Properties, then on the resulting dialog, wait for the file/folder list to build and you will find the reported size of all your files stored in your user folder
If that is the only place you store files, that is the size of your files.
Also, if you use OneDrive to sync your files online, then the contents of the Desktop, Documents and pictures folders may be synced online already and if oyu log into the new device with the same Microsoft account, then those files should automatically download to the new device.
https://onedrive.live.com/

title: Windows 24H2 refuses to install, always sticks at 87%
description:
The Windows 24H2 update has been steadfastly refusing to complete installation on my computer for weeks, always sticking at 87%. Here are my specs:
Processor	AMD Ryzen 5 5600X 6-Core Processor  3.70 GHz
Motherboard  MSI MAG X570 TOMAHAWK
GPU    NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3060 Ti
Installed RAM	32.0 GB
System type	64-bit operating system, x64-based processor
Edition	Windows 11 Home
Version	23H2
Installed on	â3/â4/â2023
OS build	22631.5909
Experience	Windows Feature Experience Pack 1000.22700.1106.0
173/464 GB free on main system drive
Here's what I've tried:

 Rebooting, hard shutdown, unplugging
 Ran sfc /scannow and several dism commands thru command prompt
 Install via Win 11 Installation Assistant
 Install via Win11_24H2 ISO file
 Ran the update troubleshooter
 Restarted Update services via services.msc
 Updated all drivers

Nothing works. 87%.  
Last attempt, I checked out Event Viewer to see if there were any system logs that could help. Did not find anything useful. The computer rebooted during update, came back at 75%, proceeded to 86 then 87%, and remained stuck for an hour, when I hard rebooted. From the update reboot to hard reboot nothing in the event viewer is visible.
Any help or advice appreciated.
answers:
Hello, James Tanner.
With such updates (change of build 23H2->24H2), there are several moments when it seems that the PC is frozen, but this is not always the case. The "freeze" can last up to 3-4 hours (sometimes longer, depending on the PC configuration). Try not to turn off the PC by 87%, but wait a few hours. Write about the result later.
I like to add along with what Alexandr S suggested that try **SetupDiag (**if it really stuck at 87% ), which is a diagnostic tool that can be used to obtain details about why a Windows upgrade was unsuccessful.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/upgrade/setupdiag
Now the picture is beginning to clear up... The error "0xC1900101 â 0x4000D" indicates a problem with the configuration of some driver. This may happen due to incompatible drivers. 
Download the following files:
minidump file: $Windows.~bt\Sources\Rollback\setupmem.dmp
Event logs: $Windows.~bt\Sources\Rollback*.evtx
Device Installation Log: $Windows.~bt\Sources\Rollback\setupapi\setupapi.dev.log
to some file sharing site, and write the link here. Analyzing these files will help you identify the "culprit" more accurately.
In the meantime, try upgrading to 24H2 via an ISO file, but before that, turn off the Internet and restart your PC in the "clean boot" mode: https://support.microsoft.com/en-gb/topic/how-to-perform-a-clean-boot-in-windows-da2f9573-6eec-00ad-2f8a-a97a1807f3dd#id0ebbd=windows_11
According to the logs, so far there is only one problem - the error is caused by the Bluetooth device driver. If it is a removable device, then physically disconnect it from the PC. If Bluetooth is built-in, then check if it can be disabled in the BIOS or try disabling it in the Device Manager. Important! Before disconnecting, remove the drivers via the Control Panel and check manually after removal (the software is installed in C:\Program Files\WIDCOMM)
Yes, you're right about mentioning the printer driver. But there is one caveat. "0x38 (CM_PROB_NEED_CLASS_CONFIG)" indicates that the device is waiting for startup and additional configuration. Alternatively, disconnect the printer from the PC and completely uninstall its drivers. And install it after the update.
Quote: "...then I used CCleaner to uninstall..."
But that's not good at all.:(The fact is that such programs generally disable the system. And in particular, CCleaner, immediately after installation and launch, starts working in the background, even if you close the program. The resident part at the driver level continues its "work". Microsoft has issued a separate warning about the use of such programs.: https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/topic/microsoft-support-policy-for-the-use-of-registry-cleaning-utilities-0485f4df-9520-3691-2461-7b0fd54e8b3a 
And that could have made the situation worse. As practice shows, the "changes" made by CCleaner are not treatable and recoverable. I recommend that you consider completely reinstalling the OS from the installation media from under the BIOS, while first saving the necessary files and data on a separate medium.

title: ntoskrnl.exe making my pc bsod
description:
i just built a new pc (specs in note) and windows 11 sometimes randomly crashes and i cant replicate the issue intentionally
after i tried using BlueScreenViewer to read the minidumps it says ntoskrnl.exe is the reason for the bsods and i tried advices from reddit and updating my drivers but i cant seem to find the bios update for my motherboard but the others are all updated
idk waht to do pls help
system specs:
intel i5 14400F
nvidia RTX 5060
asus tuf gaming B760M-plus wifi II
32 gb of ddr5 ram cosair vengence rgb
kingston nvme nv3 1tb
answers:
Hi. I'm David, and I'm happy to help you.

The BlueScreenView has not been giving reliable information recently.

Please share the minidump files.
These files are in C:\Windows\Minidump.
Copy any files you have to your desktop and store them in a ZIP file. Then, upload the ZIP file to the cloud (OneDrive), choose to share it, and get the link.
Then, post the link to the ZIP file here so I can have a look.

I await your reply.
Sorry for the delay in reply. I've been offline.

The minidumps you provided do not reference any drivers, but they all point to the system process "svchost.exe" as the cause of the crash. Since each crash shares the same stop code, "CRITICAL_PROCESS_DIED", there's a strong possibility that "svchost.exe" is corrupted or damaged.

I think it's a good idea to try the SFC (System File Checker) to fix possible corrupted system files before trying anything more intrusive.

 Open Start and type cmd, right-click on "Command Prompt", and select "Run as administrator".
 Run the following commands at the Command Prompt one at a time:

dism.exe /online /cleanup-image /scanhealth
dism.exe /online /cleanup-image /restorehealth
dism.exe /online /cleanup-image /startcomponentcleanup
sfc /scannow

Note: Pay close attention to the results of the commands. This will help you determine whether the procedure was completed successfully or if there was a problem. If you get any errors, let me know the error message that was displayed.

 Restart the PC.

After restarting the PC, see if the system will work stably.

If the BSOD occurs again, please share the minidump it created.

Feel free to ask back any questions.
In this case, I suggest you perform an In-place Upgrade. This procedure reinstalls Windows, which helps to fix problems.
But don't worry. It's a simple procedure, and you have the option to keep files, settings, and apps. Therefore, all your data is kept.
(If you have a third-party antivirus installed, temporarily disable it during the entire procedure.)

Download the ISO file to perform the procedure:

 Access the link below;

https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/software-download/windows11

 Under Download Windows 11 Disk Image (ISO), click Select download and select Windows 11 (multi-edition ISO for x64 devices);
 Click Download;
 Choose the language and click on Confirm;
 Then, click 64-bit Download.
 Wait for the download to finish and proceed to the procedure below.


After downloading the ISO, do the following:

 Double-click the ISO to run;

(After running the ISO, you may need to double-click the Setup file to start the procedure.)

 On the Install Windows 11 screen, uncheck I want to help make the installation of Windows better and select Change how Windows Setup download updates;
 On the next screen, select Not right now and click Next;
 Accept the terms of use;
 On the Ready to install screen, select Choose what to keep and select what you want to keep.

(It is in this step that you must check Keep personal files and apps so that all your data is kept.)

 Click on Install and wait for the procedure to finish. Your computer may restart several times.


After the procedure is complete, see if the system will work stably.

If you get any errors or the problem persists, please let me know.

Feel free to ask back any questions.
Sorry for the delay in reply. I've been offline.
Thanks for the clarification.

I believe that, given the issues you experienced with In-Place Upgrade, a clean install is a good idea. And there's another detail: Blue screen issues don't survive a clean install unless they're caused by a hardware issue.

To perform a clean install, you will need an installation media.
If you don't have an installation media, create one using the Media Creation Tool.
You can create the installation media on an empty USB flash drive with at least 8GB.

Below are instructions for creating installation media on a USB flash drive.

 Download the tool from the link below;

https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2156295

 Double-click on the downloaded file to run the tool;
 If prompted by UAC (User Account Control), click on "Yes";
 Read the terms and click "Accept" if you agree;
 Leave the "Use the recommended options for this PC" box checked and click "Next."
 Select "USB flash drive" and click "Next".
 Connect the USB flash drive you want to use, click the "Refresh drive list" link, select the USB flash drive, and click "Next";

(Note that the files on the USB flash drive will be deleted. Make a backup of the files if necessary.)

 Wait for the procedure to finish and click "Finish" when the USB flash drive is ready.


If necessary, make a copy of your files to an external storage device or a cloud storage service. A clean install will remove all data stored on the system drive.

Then, access the article below, go to the end of the article, and expand "Clean install" under "Steps to reinstall Windows with media" to see the instructions.
https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/reinstall-windows-with-the-installation-media-d8369486-3e33-7d9c-dccc-859e2b022fc7#:~:text=Steps%20to%20reinstall%20Windows%20with%20media
In your case, start the computer using the installation media and proceed from step 2.
(You may need to change the BOOT property in the device's BIOS settings. If you don't know how to do this, let me know.)

Feel free to ask back any questions.

title: How to fix crashing Unity Engine games?
description:
I've been struggling with this issue and I'm at a loss with this ongoing issue, and I feel like this may be a hardware issue, but my other games that aren't made with Unity Engine work on my PC. I've tried verifying game files, uninstalling and reinstalling, clear cache, etc. but no results.  
Games that were made with Unity Engine like, Potion Permit, Tiny Bookshop, Waterpark Simulator had been hanging and whenever I click the mouse, they crashed on startup. Is there any permanent fix for this problem?
answers:
Hi ,
If it is a laptop or desktop, if possible, could you provide the laptop model or your desktop configuration?  
Thanks

title: Failure to boot after update
description: I Have a message when PC is turned on that reads "Something didn't go as planned. No need to worry--undoing changes. Please keep your computer on" after windows automatic update. The PC has been on this screen for over 10 hours now.
answers:
Force your PC to shut down by pressing and holding the Power button on the case of your PC for 5 - 10 seconds.
Wait a few seconds, then try to boot into the recovery environment using these steps.
Start your PC, just as Windows attempts to load (spinning dots), press and hold Power Button for 5 - 10 seconds to perform a Hard Shut Down 
Do this twice 
On the third start Windows will boot into the Recovery Environment and from there you can access System Repair, Safe Mode, Command Prompt... etc. 
Try each option one at a time, then see if Windows will boot up correctly.
.
If there is an option to uninstall the latest update, that may be the best option.
.
Go to Troubleshoot - Advanced Option - Startup Repair 
See if Windows startup can repair itself.
Go to Troubleshoot - Advanced Option - System Restore 
Check to see if you have a restore point you can go back to

title: Why isn't the Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-3610QM CPU @ 2.30GHz compatible with Windows 11?
description: This processor more than meets the the speed requirements and is a quad core.  Why exactly is this not on the list of compatible processors?
answers: The Intel Core i7-3610QM is a good strong processor, but it is a 3rd generation processor from late 2012, the minimum requirements for Windows 11 is an 8th generation Intel processor, Microsoft indicate it is not about the strength or speed of the processor, it is about the security features supported by the processor, also, if that is your processor model, you will not have a TPM 2.0 chip on your motherboard, that would also be another feature blocking the upgrade to Windows 11.

title: Laptop goes into Windows Recovery when left unattended
description:
I use my laptop often, but sometimes when I leave it asleep for a while, it will go into Windows Recovery on its own. I come back, and the bluescreen is already showing. Choosing to restart the laptop allows me to use it as normal again. Nothing is ever missing or out of place, as far as I can tell.
It doesn't do this when just the screen is alseep (i.e. I have music playing), or if the laptop has been shut down completely.
I don't know what would be causing this. It's very annoying because then I lose unsaved progress and have to reopen/relogin to everything again.
I don't know if I can reproduce it because it seems to be random at best (a few minutes to a few hours), and I use my laptop very frequently during the day for school/leisure, and to play music for me to sleep to at night, so it doesn't get to just sleep often.
answers:
Hi rose, welcome in community 
check the path 
windows\minidump
and check if there are dmp files in it, if yes upload them in your onedrive and share here the link for analyze them
http://windows.microsoft.com/en-us/onedrive/share-file-folder
Troubleshoot blue screen errors
https://support.microsoft.com/en-US/windows/resolving-blue-screen-errors-in-windows-60b01860-58f2-be66-7516-5c45a66ae3c6
also perform a clean boot
https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/kb/929135
let me know
Elvis
